div.head: About this document
div.p: This document proposes the addition of a TEI module for correspondence. It is the product of a Correspondence SIG task force (Sabine Seifert, Marcel Illetschko, Peter Stadler) with valuable input from various people.

The aim of the proposal is to define a common set of correspondence-specific meta data, brought together at one place in the TEI header. The lack of special guidelines for encoding letters, postcards, etc. with TEI P5 has been a recurring topic since the formation of the Correspondence SIG in 2008. Additionally, there is a growing demand of correspondence projects for linked data facilities. While some of this correspondence-specific information can already be encoded in various sections of the TEI header we believe it to be of greater value for projects dealing with correspondence material to have this information in one place. For the encoding, we suggest two approaches within this set:
an elaborate structure for detailed data capture,
a basic structure for easy data interchange (CIF). A guiding idea has been to only tentatively modify the TEI standard by merely adding a few elements, wrapping them in a special purpose element ct:correspDesc and injecting the latter into sourceDesc. Please note that ct:correspDesc is not intended to and can not replace the whole TEI header.
These efforts are supposed to be just a first step in the Correspondence SIG's strive for a complete model of encoding correspondence material.

div.head: Conventions used
div.p: As required for TEI conformance, non-TEI elements are defined in a distinct non-TEI namespace. In the usage examples and throughout this document that namespace is mapped to the prefix ct: (= correspondence task force), while TEI elements are not marked by any namespace prefix.

div.head: Preceding work
div.p: The development of ct:correspDesc was inspired mostly but not exclusively by the work of DALF as well as the WeGA.

The DALF project, the Digital Archive of Letters by Flemish Authors and Composers from the 19th & 20th century, was launched by the Belgian Centre for Scholarly Editing and Document Studies (Centrum voor Teksteditie en Bronnenstudie) and is one of the best documented projects in the area of correspondence encoding. In 2003, specific DTDs and guidelines for the description and encoding of modern correspondence material, both for TEI P4, were published. The practical realization as well as the main features for encoding meta data are discussed in . The DALF guidelines have been reworked for the new requirements in TEI P5 as a “Preliminary P5 Proposal” in August 2013 which is an important inspiration for this proposal.

Before DALF updated its customization from P4 to P5, the Carl-Maria-von-Weber-Gesamtausgabe (WeGA, Carl Maria von Weber – Collected Works) had developed project-specific guidelines for encoding correspondence material in TEI P5 and published recommendations in June 2011.

Both projects define a special wrapper element for correspondence meta data while the depth of its structure and its child elements differ slightly. This wrapper element (DALF:letDesc and WEGA:correspDesc, respectively) is part of the sourceDesc element. Dalf introduces two child elements: first, DALF:letHeading in which they encode the author and addressee of the letter as well as place and date when it was written, and second, DALF:letDesc which contains additional information, e.g. formal classification of the letter, presence of an envelope or illustrations. The WEGA, however, groups these information directly within the wrapper element: senderIn regard to the person who wrote the letter or other piece of correspondence, there is a conceptual difference. Thus, it is author in DALF and sender in WeGA. and addressee, place and date where and when the letter was not only written but also received, incipit and position within the thread of correspondence (“Korrespondenzstelle”). Both projects decided to leave all other information on providence, physical appearance, history, etc. in msDesc where there already are sufficient elements to encode them with.
In this proposal, we mainly considered the overlapping of these two projects’ encoding guidelines and merged them into one.

div.head: Theoretical Considerations
div.p: In this document correspondence is regarded as an act of communication, in which the message of a sender reaches—mediated and time-delayed—an addressee at a different place. Such an act of communication becomes manifest in a piece of correspondence, that may be a tangible “object”, characterised by its “materiality” and co-determining the communication, and that is generally related to a medium or process of delivery. Hence, correspondence has a hybrid nature between event and object.

As an act of communication is directed at someone, each piece of correspondence has one or more addressees, who may or may not be individually identifiable. Therefore, the scope of "correspondence" in this proposal covers not only letters, postcards, telegrams, and similar "material" pieces of correspondence but also electronic communications, e.g. e-mails and text messages.

div.head: What is—in terms of the TEI—correspondence-specific information?
div.p: An act of communication has a sender of a message (ct:sender), who is not necessarily identical to the author of the text of the message.
An act of communication generally has no unknown audience/unspecified recipient but one or more (intended, maybe even fictional) addressees (ct:addressee), “spoken” to by the piece of correspondence.

A piece of correspondence generally has a certain time or period of writing and a definable time of sending—even though it may be unknown or indeterminate (ct:dateSender). Similar is true for the place of writing/sending (ct:placeSender). Both very often is evident in address lines, postmarks, electronically generated sending information, etc.
A piece of correspondence generally has a process/a medium of transfer (messenger, carrier, postman, carriage, fax machine, internet, etc.) (ct:transmission).

Very often a particular message is sent in order to trigger an answer (in form of one or more pieces of correspondence). A single piece of correspondence therefore is normally not a secluded entity but a (written) act of communication in a communication continuum, in which it is defined by its relative position between messages sent “before” and “after” (ct:context).

div.head: And what is left out?
div.p: Information concerning the manuscript description, e.g. (postage) stamps, seals, water marks, form fields, letter heads, or incipits, are not considered part of the proposed correspondence description. These aspects are not necessarily correspondence-specific but rather characteristic for manuscripts in general and are thus best encoded within msDesc.

As this proposal deals with the meta data of correspondence, aspects relating to correspondence-specific transcriptional encoding within text, e.g. with postscript, opener, closer, or signed, are not considered.

div.head: Implementation of the correspondence description
div.p: The correspDesc element provides a detailed description of correspondence-specific metadata. The correspDesc element focuses on the communicative function of correspondence, i.e. sender, addressee, transmission. It is provided as a supplement to the physical description of a correspondence object which is to be encoded within the sourceDesc. The description is organized by the following elements

A simple example might be encoded as follows:
Adelbert von Chamisso
Louis de La Foye
Vertus
Caen
29 January 1807
lettersheet signed personally
Previous letter of Adelbert von Chamisso to Louis de La Foye: 16 January 1807 Next letter of Adelbert von Chamisso to Louis de La Foye: 07 May 1810
Post

By default, order and number of the above elements are not constraint facilitating the encoding of several entities of each feature provided that they all belong to the same communication process. Hence, it is possible to differentiate between the intended and the actual (place of) addressee with the type attribute. In other cases, the respective elements are simply repeated. See for example the postcard of the gathered philologists in Prague to their colleague Seuffert in Graz on the occasion of the first informal Germanistenabend which features several sender elements with one entry each:
Adolf Hauffen
Hans Lambel
Hans Meyer
Richard Rosenbaum
August Sauer
Hans Tschinkel
Franz Werner
Spiridion Wukadinović
Bernhard Seuffert
Prag
Graz
22.01.1898

div.head: Names, actors, places and dates of correspondence
div.p:
Usually, the sender and the author of a message are identical. To reduce the redundancy of markup and error-proneness, standard linking mechanisms can be applied to connect the author element within titleStmt to the appropriate sender element.
In other cases (cf. the example of collaborative authorship above), there might as well be a clear distinction of the intellectual author of the text and the sender of the message, be it in disguise or frankly. Examples include pre-formulated greeting cards, forced dictated messages, or copied love letters. In such cases, the genuine author is encoded as author within titleStmt, as usual.

The placeSender and placeAddressee elements are provided to capture the names of spatial locations of sender and addressee respectivly. It is possible to differentiate those places further with the type attribute, e.g. to distinguish the intended place of the addressee (as noted on the address) from the actual place of reception; or to capture several places of writing when the letter was produced over several days at several places. Where applicable, these names can be encoded in more detail with elements provided by the namesdates module described in 13 Names, Dates, People, and Places. If an (external) placeography is present or authority files are available it is also highly recommended to identify those places via unique URIs.
Prag
Graz

As with other information compiled within correspDesc, the spatial information is supposed to be editorial, normalised data, not necessarily the exact reproduction of the original address which should rather be encoded within text. However, it is possible to provide more address-like detail:
SubMarine Telegraph Company 58 Threadneedle Street London EC

Because a piece of correspondence generally has a process/a medium of transfer the transmission element allows to clearly identify e.g. messenger (Pheidippides who orally delivers the news of the victory against the Persians from Marathon to Athens), carrier (person who takes Goethe's letters to Charlotte Schiller), postman (official letter carrier), carriage, fax machine etc. The transmission element therefor in some respect is related to channel in the 15.2.1 Text Description (for example regarding the technical channel internet for emails), but it may also refer to persons involved in the process of communcation/transmission as well as to the method of transmission without assigning responsibility to a person, organisation etc. Transmission can both be used as an empty element with according type (and subtype) attributes or in a more verbose way with child element.

div.head: Context and classification of correspondence
div.p:
The exact position of a piece of correspondence as an act of communication within a communication continuum is a defining feature. This position between a preceding and a following message is encoded within ct:context. The conception of the exact position, the Korrespondenzstelle, might differ between projects in relation to the respective understanding of the extent of the correspondence, e.g. all known letters between person A and B in several repositories vs. just the letters from person A to person B of one collection in one repository. For the encoding of the previous and following piece of correspondences, ref or ptr elements may be used with attributes or p for a general description, as follows:
Previous letter of August Sauer to Bernhard Seuffert: 30. December 1897 Next letter of August Sauer to Bernhard Seuffert: 01. February 1898

Although questions of materiality can already be encoded within the sourceDesc (i.e. in most cases within the msDesc) pieces of correspondence may be categorized in terms of their object- and/or eventlike nature (e.g. letter, signed personally; telegram; picture postcard; copy; draft) within the correspDesc element. Therefore, the correspClass element may be used by reference to a (external) classification scheme as used in library and documentation work (@scheme). By the use of the term element different categories can be implemented as child elements within the correspClass element.

div.head: Correspondence Interchange Format (CIF)
div.p: Next to encoding with an elaborate structure for detailed data capture, there is the possibility to use the basic structure of the Correspondence Interchange Format (CIF). It is designed to enable easy data interchange between digital editions and projects and is used in combination with established standards, e.g. authorial files for persons and places, ISO-codes for dates, etc.

div.head: Future Work
div.p:
After dealing with correspondence-specific meta data, the next steps are:
restructuring correspondence-related transcriptional elements, as there are several problems with elements like postscript, opener, closer, etc.
developing best practice recommendations, with examples, for the encoding of correspondence material.
